entry.et: Middle English, from Old English flǣsc; akin to Old High German fleisk flesh and perhaps to Old English flēan to flay flay

def.dt: :the soft parts of the body of an animal and especially of a vertebrate
:the parts composed chiefly of skeletal muscle as distinguished from internal organs, bone, and integument
:the condition of having ample fat on the body cattle in good flesh
:flesh of a mammal or fowl eaten as food
:the physical nature of human beings the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak Matthew 26:41(Authorized Version)
:a fleshy plant part used as food
:substance insights buried in the flesh of the narrative Jan Carew
:to initiate or habituate especially by giving a foretaste
:to clothe or cover with or as if with flesh
:to give substance to usually used with out flesh out a plan
:to make fuller or more nearly complete used with out museums fleshing out their collections with borrowed works
:to become fleshy often used with up or out
:corporeal nature as composed of flesh and of blood
:near kindred used chiefly in the phrase one's own flesh and blood
:a dipteran fly whose maggots feed on flesh
:any of a family (Sarcophagidae) of flies some of which cause myiasis
:the act of greeting and shaking hands with people especially while campaigning for political office
:an injury involving penetration of the body musculature without damage to bones or internal organs
:a payment or penalty exacted to fulfill a deal or punishment loan sharks taking their pound of flesh

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French presser, from Latin pressare, frequentative of premere to press; probably akin to Russian naperet' to press

def.dt: :to act upon through steady pushing or thrusting force exerted in contact :squeeze
:to squeeze out the juice or contents of
:to squeeze with apparatus or instruments to a desired density, smoothness, or shape
:to make (a phonograph record) from a matrix
:to require haste or speed in action
:to greet and shake hands with people especially while campaigning for political office
